author: Mohamed Imranullah S
text:
All ‘Agamas’ (Hindu religious scriptures) are not available now in full and hence opinions formed even by experts on the basis of available materials are divided and interpreted differently by different scholars just as every law is capable of being interpreted by lawyers in different ways, the Madras High Court Bench here has said.

A Division Bench of Justices V. Ramasubramanian and N. Kirubakaran made the observation while dismissing two public interest litigation petitions against proposed consecration of Sri Ramanathaswamy Temple in Rameswaram on January 20 on the ground that the ceremony had been fixed in violation of ‘Karana Agama’ that governed rituals in the temple.

Stating that ‘Agama’ primarily meant tradition, the judges said that the six indigenous religions — Saivam, Vaishnavam, Saaktham, Kaumaram, Sauram and Gaanaapatyam — had their own Agamas earlier. But most of those Agamas were lost after their unification by eighth century theologian Adi Sankara.

“What survive today are only 28 Saiva Agamas and two principal Vaishnavite Agamas. It appears that Saiva Agamas are classified into four types namely Siddhantha Saivagamas, Paasupatha Saivagamas, Kaapalika Saivagamas and Kaalamukha Saivagamas. All the 28 Saiva Agamas, on the basis of which most of the temples in Tamil Nadu are built, belong to Siddhantha Saivagamas,” they said.

Under statutory prescriptions, general rule must yield to

special rule
title: Agamas prone to different interpretations: HC
